results.title: More Winners: Boy Soldiers
results.creator_credit: Cliff Green, Mark Joffe, Margot McDonald, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Australian Children's Television Foundation and Quartier Latin International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In 1910 the Australian Government passed a law requiring all boys aged between 14 and 17 years of age to register for compulsory military training. Between 1911 and 1915, more than 30,000 boys were persecuted for failing to obey this law. This story tells of one such boy, Will Barnes, a 14 year old conscientious objector who refuses to register. After prosecution Will is sentenced to three months training at Fort Queenscliff. At the fort, Will refuses to wear a uniform or to be involved in any type of military training. Will meets a lot of opposition but also wins his share of admirers, for sticking to his beliefs.

Cast includes Tamblyn Lord, Nathan Croft, Bruno Lawrence, Nicholas Bell and Gary Sweet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cliff Green, Mark Joffe, Margot McDonald, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Australian Children’s Television Foundation and Quartier Latin International

results.title: How does your garden grow?
results.creator_credit: George Cass, Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Kevin Heinze shows young students various aspects of gardening using simple techniques suitable for the classroom. Topics covered in this 5 part series are: 1) Sowing seeds; 2) Propagating plants; 3) Potting up; 4) Carnivorous plants; 5) Arbor Week.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Cass, Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch and TV Ed Productions

results.title: Aclà
results.creator_credit: Aurelio Grimaldi, Camilla Nesbitt, Pietro Valsecchi, Pentafilm, Nova Films and CineEuropa '92
results.brief_description: In the 1930s and 11-year-old Sicilian boy, Acla, is sold to a sulphur miner, and for five years from Monday to Saturday, the boy is made the miner’s property, spending the whole week down the mine, going home on Saturday and Sunday. There he experiences the inhuman world of the sulphur mines, the stifling, choking tunnels and the physical and sexual violence that everybody indulges in by unspoked agreement. He attempts several escapes, but each time he is caught and beaten. Until the last attempt, when finally he reaches the sea. And freedom… In Italian language with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aurelio Grimaldi, Camilla Nesbitt, Pietro Valsecchi, Pentafilm, Nova Films and CineEuropa ‘92
results.description: In the 1930s and 11-year-old Sicilian boy, Acla, is sold to a sulphur miner, and for five years from Monday to Saturday, the boy is made the miner’s property, spending the whole week down the mine, going home on Saturday and Sunday. There he experiences the inhuman world of the sulphur mines, the stifling, choking tunnels and the physical and sexual violence that everybody indulges in by unspoked agreement. He attempts several escapes, but each time he is caught and beaten. Until the last attempt, when finally he reaches the sea. And freedom… In Italian language with English subtitles.

results.title: Trade routes
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Richard Guthrie
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Professor Eric Willmot describes the ancient trade routes set up by the Aborigines all over the continent, the evidence for their existence and the effect they had on the structure of Aboriginal society. 100,000 years ago the first people came to Australia. A thriving trade in stone age technology, and in red ochre began. The law of ancient Australia, of beholdenness, and all its implications, still followed by tribal Aborigines today, was derived from this trade. But the trade routes also carried destruction in the form of disease and white settlers. Yet many are still used, albeit using different methods of transport and trading new commodities.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Richard Guthrie

results.title: Rolf Harris: How to Draw Fun Cartoons
results.brief_description: Yes, it’s the distinctive cartoons, drawings and humour of the unstoppable Rolf Harris and it’s Rolf Harris in person taking you through your very own “learn to draw” lesson. “You can draw”, says Rolf Harris. “We all can. It’s just a matter of knowing that you can draw your way”. How to draw fun cartoons, will give you as much pleasure watching as it will when you try out Rolf’s methods for yourself. Don’t say “I can’t draw” anymore, let Rolf Harris show you how.
